etymologies: Old English lætra ‘slower’, comparative of læt (see late)

notes.text: Latter means ‘the second-mentioned of two.’ Its use to mean ‘the last-mentioned of three or more’ is common, but is considered incorrect by some because latter means ‘later’ rather than ‘latest.’ Last or last-mentioned is preferred where three or more things are involved. See also former

definitions: situated or occurring nearer to the end of something than to the beginning

examples.text: heart disease dogged his latter years

shortDefinitions: occurring or situated nearer to end of something than to beginning

examples.text: the project had low cash flows in its latter years

definitions: denoting the second or second mentioned of two people or things

examples.text: the Russians could advance into either Germany or Austria—they chose the latter option

shortDefinitions: denoting second or second mentioned of two people or things
